meeting_annotations.speaker: Robert Bryan Jr
meeting_annotations.transcript: All right, let me let me start off with a question. So, Tim and who Oh, I guess it was JP mentioned that, um, I got from your talk that certain bacteria becoming associated with certain phenotypic changes in the brain. Is is that correct? I understand you guys, right? One of our problems is we get a lot of changes that we see, but identifying those bacteria that are responsible for the changes is is a different task. And let's couch this in terms of neuroinflammation. How do you guys go about identifying a group or small group or individual bacteria that are good or bad?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Tim Sampson
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, so I think at least in the case of Parkinson's disease where at least our group is leveraging a lot of the existing human data that's out there to understand those microbes that are most closely associated with the disease state. And again, at least with Parkinson's disease, there's a plethora now of of samples, so on the order of thousands, I think now that have been sequenced pretty deeply. So we can see not just associations and presence or absence of particular microbes, but actually enrichments and correlations with different aspects of disease severity, things like the constipation phenotypes that happen in these patient populations. Um, things like severity of the motor symptoms, rapid we don't quite have progression yet in PD is a pretty long disorder that takes a long time to progress. So to my knowledge, we don't have that sort of temporal resolution, but we do have sort of that cross-sectional resolution of of disease severity. And so I think that is that's been the first kind of low-hanging fruit that that we can then test experimentally in some of these animal models. So for instance, asking if those microbes that are enriched in patients that have the worst symptoms, do they induce the worst or a significant amount of inflammation or pathology in the brains of gnotobiotic mice? So I think that's at least the way that my lab approaches that conundrum. And it really is just these association studies, which again for PD are are pretty powerful, but for other disorders, maybe not as much.
